prompts: We’re new parents with a 10-day-old who mostly breastfeeds but takes an occasional 2 oz formula bottle at night. How often should we be feeding during the day and overnight, should we wake the baby to feed, how long should a typical nursing session be per side, and how often should we burp? Also, how many wet/dirty diapers should we expect in 24 hours to know they’re getting enough, and what are signs of overfeeding with bottles?

Can you give me quick guidance on safe newborn sleep? Specifically: the safest sleep position, whether swaddling is okay and when to stop, how to dress a baby for sleep in a 70°F (21°C) room (how many layers), and simple signs that the baby is too hot or too cold.

I’m 6 weeks postpartum and want to combo feed when I go back to work in 2 weeks. Baby is gaining well and currently eats every 2–3 hours; bottles are about 3 oz when we use them. Can you suggest a simple plan for when to nurse vs. give a bottle, how often I should pump during an 8-hour workday, and roughly how much milk to leave for that time window? Please keep it straightforward.

Our 7-week-old has been exclusively breastfed and is refusing the bottle. We’ve tried two brands (Dr. Brown’s and Comotomo) and different times of day, but no luck. Can you share practical tips to help a breastfed baby accept a bottle, including whether to use a slow-flow nipple and how to do paced bottle feeding? A concise checklist would be great.

My baby just turned 6 months, is sitting with support and showing interest in our food. We want to start with baby-led weaning. Could you suggest a simple first meal with 3–4 starter finger foods, how to cut/prepare them to reduce choking risk, and a quick note on gagging vs choking? We have no known family allergies—how can we safely include peanut early (e.g., thinned peanut butter), and how much should we offer the first time?

We started solids at 5.5 months with purees; now at 6.5 months we want to shift toward baby-led weaning. What’s a safe way to offer self-fed versions of banana, avocado, roasted sweet potato, and scrambled egg for a baby with two bottom teeth? Please include basic prep/cut shapes, whether seasoning is okay, and roughly how often to offer solids alongside breastmilk in a day.

We’re ready to start gentle sleep training for our 6‑month‑old. Details: 6 months, 18 lbs, exclusively breastfed, sleeps in crib in his own room with blackout/white noise and a sleep sack. Current routine: bedtime 7:30 pm after bath/feed/books; we rock to drowsy. He takes 3 naps totaling ~3 hours (last nap ends ~4:45 pm). Night: dream feed at 10:30 pm, then he wakes around 1:30 am and 4:30 am to feed; up for the day ~6:30 am. We’d like to use a Ferber-style approach with check-ins and keep one feeding overnight for now. Can you give a concise plan for the first 3 nights (check-in intervals, how long to wait before feeding, what to do if he wakes <3 hours after last feed) plus a simple 20–30 minute bedtime routine? Please keep it brief, bullet points ok.

How can we fix chronic 5:00 am wake-ups for our 10‑month‑old? Current schedule: up ~6:00 am, nap 1: 9:15–9:55 (40 min), nap 2: 1:30–2:30 (1 hr), bedtime 7:00 pm. Room is dark with white noise, uses a pacifier, two bottles during the day plus solids 3x/day (total ~22–24 oz formula). He wakes happy at 5:00 am and won’t resettle. Can you suggest concise tweaks (e.g., nap caps/lengths, wake windows, bedtime shift, how to respond to wakes before 6:00 am) to nudge wake-up closer to 6:30 am? Keep the advice short and practical.

My 6-week-old cries hard every evening from about 6-9 pm. We formula-feed (3 oz every ~3 hours), burp after feeds, and diaper is fine. We have a swaddle, pacifier, white-noise app, a yoga ball, and a dim, quiet apartment. What’s a simple, safe soothing plan I can try tonight (5-7 steps), and when should I call the pediatrician in case it’s more than colic?

For a gassy, fussy 2-month-old, can you give me quick, step-by-step instructions for tummy massage and bicycle legs to relieve gas/colic? Please include how much pressure, how long, how often, and any safety precautions (like timing around feeds).

My 7-month-old seems to be teething—lots of drool, gnawing, and cranky at night. What are a few safe, simple ways to relieve the pain at home? Please include ideas for daytime and bedtime, and note any red flags that mean we should call the pediatrician. We’d prefer to avoid medicated gels.

I’m a nanny caring for a 5-month-old who’s likely teething. We can’t use medications at daycare. We’ve tried a chilled silicone teether with limited success. Can you suggest 5 drug-free soothing strategies we can use during the day (no freezer items allowed), and mention anything we should avoid (e.g., amber necklaces, numbing gels)?

My son is 26 months old. Signs observed: tells us when he poops but hides to pee, diapers stay dry for 2-3 hours, can pull pants up/down with help, resists sitting on the potty, and is scared of flushing. Is he ready to start potty training? If yes, what gentle method would you suggest for a working family with daycare (they allow pull-ups only)?

We’re on week 2 of daytime potty training with my 3-year-old. He pees on the potty if prompted but rarely initiates, and we get 1-2 pee accidents when he’s engrossed in play. What’s a simple way to transition from adult reminders to self-initiated trips? Would a timer, sticker chart, or potty watch work better?

My 2.5-year-old melts down when I turn off the TV—screaming, hitting, and throwing the remote. What’s the best way to handle the tantrum in the moment, and how can I prevent it next time? Please suggest a short script I can say, how long to hold the boundary, and whether to use time-in or time-out.

Help with public tantrums: My 3-year-old had a full meltdown at the grocery store over candy (lying on the floor, kicking). I was alone with a baby in a stroller and didn’t know what to do. What’s a simple step-by-step plan for the moment (what to say, whether to leave the cart, how to keep everyone safe) and how to debrief afterward to reduce repeat episodes?

Help! My 4-year-old is super picky—loves plain pasta, yogurt, and chicken nuggets, but refuses mixed dishes and anything green. No medical issues. We eat together at 6 pm. Can you give me 3 family dinner ideas that include visible vegetables in a non-threatening way, plus a simple script for offering and declining without pressure?

I'm an adult picky eater trying to expand my palate. I dislike slimy or bitter foods and get overwhelmed by strong smells. I want to start liking mushrooms and salmon. Can you outline a 10-day plan with small daily steps (buying, prep, tasting) and suggest 4 beginner-friendly recipes that gradually build up intensity? Also, a couple tips for managing texture and smell.

Help me design a simple, screen-free 25–30 minute bedtime routine for my 2-year-old who fights sleep and stalls (asks for more water and “one more story”). We live in a small apartment, do baths every other night, and use white noise. Bedtime target is 7:30 pm. Please give a step-by-step routine with approximate times, a short sample script I can say during transitions, and 3 quick tips for handling protests without power struggles.

My 3-year-old is moving from a crib to a toddler bed. Bedtime keeps sliding later because he naps 1–1.5 hours at daycare. We co-parent across two homes and want something consistent. Can you suggest a 20-minute, no-bath wind-down routine that works in both places, include two calming activities, and a brief plan for when he gets out of bed (e.g., walk-back method)? Also, recommend simple room lighting and sound cues.

I'm a 10th grader who has to catch the bus at 7:15. I set my alarm for 6:20 but lose time scrolling on my phone and end up skipping breakfast. I need a quick routine that includes a 5-minute skincare, a 10-minute breakfast, and remembering gym clothes. Can you give me a simple timestamped morning plan and 5 concrete hacks to stop phone distractions?

I’m a parent of two kids (6 and 8) with a shared bathroom and a bus pickup at 7:35. One is a picky eater and the other moves slowly unless the steps are super clear. Can you outline a simple step-by-step weekday morning routine (10 steps or fewer) plus a short night-before prep list (5 items) to reduce stress and get us out the door on time?

Can you help me quickly set up screen time limits for my 8-year-old using Google Family Link on her Android tablet? We already connected her account in Family Link. I want: (1) daily limits of 1.5 hours on school days and 2.5 hours on weekends, (2) bedtime lock from 8:00 pm to 7:00 am, (3) app caps of 20 minutes/day for YouTube Kids and 30 minutes/day for Roblox, (4) block the browser, and (5) always allow Calculator, Camera, and an audiobook app. Please give brief steps in Family Link and any on-device settings to prevent bypass (guest mode, installing new apps, etc.).

I’m trying to rein in my own screen time. On iPhone, my daily average is ~4h, and I mostly use Instagram, TikTok, and Reddit between 7–10 pm. I want to limit those three to a total of 60 minutes nightly without breaking important notifications. How should I set up Screen Time (App Limits, Downtime, and a Focus) to hit that goal, and what are 3 simple habits I can add to make it stick?

Help me set up a simple, repeatable conflict-resolution routine for my kids (Eli, 6, and Maya, 9). They bicker daily over a single iPad after school. Constraints: we only have 15 minutes before dinner, I don’t want to add screen time overall, and I’d like them to practice solving it themselves with me as a coach. Please give: (1) a 4–5 step routine I can teach them, (2) a short coaching script I can say when a fight starts, and (3) a fair rotation rule for the iPad that reduces flare-ups.

Could you help me draft a short text to my older brother about resolving our recurring fights over caring for our dad? Context: I live 20 minutes away and can do weekday evenings; he lives 2 hours away and prefers weekends but often cancels last minute. I want to propose a clear schedule, agree on what counts as an emergency, and set a check-in call each Sunday. Please write a respectful message (under 120 words) that invites his input and avoids blame, plus 2 brief alternative schedule options.

My 4-year-old melts down when it’s time to leave the playground. I want to use positive discipline, not threats or bribes. Can you give me a short, practical plan for smoother transitions that includes: 1) advance warnings/visual timer, 2) limited choices, 3) empathy + firm follow-through, 4) a simple routine, and 5) two example phrases I can say in the moment? Keep it to 8 bullet points max.

I’m a first-year 7th-grade teacher. One student blurts out answers and talks over classmates. I want positive discipline strategies—not punitive ones—to teach and reinforce hand-raising. Can you give me a brief plan that covers clear expectations, a neutral signal/cue, behavior practice, specific praise, a logical consequence, and a short restorative check-in script for after class? Please keep it under 200 words.

I'm terrible at starting conversations at work. I’m a new hire on a software team where people are friendly but quiet. Can you give me 5 natural small-talk openers I can use in the kitchen or before meetings, and 3 polite ways to end a chat without sounding rude? Please keep the examples short and specific.

I accidentally double-booked and skipped my cousin’s birthday dinner without telling her. I want to apologize and repair things. Can you draft a sincere text message (2–3 sentences) and a quick in-person apology I can say the next time I see her, plus one concrete make-it-right gesture that fits a college-student budget?

Tonight I’ve got 90 minutes to do: (1) 10 algebra practice problems (chapter 5 factoring) and (2) read/annotate 8 pages from my U.S. history textbook (pp. 142–149). I get distracted by my phone and roommates. Can you give me a short, step-by-step plan with time blocks, when to take breaks, and 3 quick tactics to stay off my phone? Please keep it concise enough to follow at a glance.

I’m preparing for finals next week in biology, calculus, and sociology. I have 2 hours available Monday–Friday after 7 pm and 4 hours on Saturday. Can you suggest a simple weekly study schedule using Pomodoro and spaced repetition, plus 2 active-recall ideas per subject? I don’t need a long essay—just a compact plan.

My 8-year-old says she “doesn’t like reading,” but she loves mysteries and Minecraft. We have about 20 minutes on school nights after dinner, limited budget, and access to a public library. Can you suggest a very simple Mon–Fri reading routine (20 minutes each day) plus 4 quick motivation ideas that don’t involve extra screen time? Keep it brief and practical.

We’re a bilingual (Spanish–English) home with a 5-year-old pre-reader and a very active 3-year-old. Please give us a short checklist (max 6 items) for setting up a cozy reading corner and a 10-minute bedtime read-aloud ritual, plus 3 bilingual picture book recommendations we can likely find at the library. Keep it concise.

It's pouring and I'm stuck inside with my 5- and 8-year-old in a small apartment. We have: blankets, pillows, two big cardboard boxes, markers, tape, a deck of cards, LEGO, balloons, basic baking ingredients (flour, sugar, eggs, baking powder), and masking tape. Can you suggest 5 or 6 low-mess indoor activities we can do today, each with 1–2 sentences on how to play or set up? Please avoid screens.

Rainy Sunday date day: we're a couple at home, looking for cozy, screen-free activities that cost under $20 and take about 60–90 minutes each. We have tea, a couple of board games, a few candles, and basic pantry staples. Can you give us 4 or 5 ideas with brief setup notes and the vibe for each (e.g., playful, mindful, romantic)?

Can you create a simple nature scavenger hunt for a 5-year-old in an urban park (grass, trees, no water features) using just a paper bag and crayons? Please include 8 items to find by color/texture and one short mindfulness moment to do during the walk.

We’re camping this weekend in a dark-sky area. What are 5 easy night-time outdoor play ideas for two kids (ages 8 and 10) that use only a flashlight and a blanket? Please include a quick safety note for each idea.

Can you give me a quick, mess-minimal science activity for my 6-year-old using only items we have: a clear glass, water, baking soda, vinegar, food coloring, raisins, and a spoon? Please include: 1) a short materials list using those items, 2) simple steps (5 or fewer), 3) a one-paragraph kid-friendly science explanation, and 4) one cleanup or safety tip. We have about 15 minutes.

I'm a 3rd-grade teacher planning a 45-minute STEM + art project to explore symmetry and fractions with basic supplies (copy paper, scissors, crayons/markers, glue). Propose one project with brief learning goals, 6–8 concise steps, and a quick assessment idea I can do in 5 minutes at the end. Keep instructions kid-friendly.

My 18-month-old only says a few words (mama, ball, uh-oh) but babbles a lot. He loves toy cars and bath time. Can you suggest 4 quick, play-based activities to encourage expressive language, with 2–3 simple model phrases I can use for each activity and a tip on how long to pause to let him try?

We’re a bilingual home (English/Spanish). Our 3-year-old understands both but often answers with pointing or “mmm.” Can you give me 5 low-pressure prompts I can use in daily routines (like meals, getting dressed, play) with a short expected child response in both languages? Keep each example really short.

We live in an English-dominant area, but we speak Spanish at home. My 3-year-old understands Spanish but usually replies in English. Can you suggest a simple daily routine with two or three 5–10 minute activities to strengthen Spanish, plus a handful of ready-made Spanish prompts I can say to encourage him to answer in Spanish without pressure? Also, is it okay if he mixes the two languages at this age?

I’m the Mandarin-speaking parent and my spouse only speaks English. Our 7-year-old attends an English-medium school and resists reading in Mandarin. We can spare about 15 minutes before bed. Could you give me three practical, low-screen ideas to improve Mandarin reading at home, and advice on how to correct tones or character mistakes gently so I don’t discourage him? We have some picture books, sticky notes, and no tutor.

Yesterday my manager called my presentation 'sloppy' and I’ve been stuck replaying it. Could you give me: (1) three compassionate self-talk phrases I can use today, (2) two quick cognitive reframes for the thought 'I’m not good enough,' and (3) a simple 7-day resilience micro-plan with one action per day (each under 5 minutes) to rebuild confidence at work?

I’m a first‑gen college student juggling two part‑time jobs and classes, and my self-esteem dips when I compare myself to classmates with more support. Please give me: (1) five strengths-based affirmations tailored to my situation, (2) three short journal prompts to help me focus on my values, and (3) a 60‑second grounding routine I can do between classes.

My 12-year-old has been getting teased and left out in her class group chat—kids are making jokes about her clothes and not inviting her to hangouts. How can I talk to her in a supportive way tonight, and what are two or three steps I should take with the school? If possible, include a short sample email (3–4 sentences) I can send to her homeroom teacher.

I think I’m being bullied at work by a colleague who interrupts me, takes credit for my ideas, and makes sarcastic remarks in meetings. Can you give me three clear, assertive phrases I can use in the moment, plus a brief plan for documenting incidents and appropriately escalating if it continues?

Can you help me figure out if this is a phishing email? Here’s the exact message I received:

From: PayPal Security <security@paypalsecure-alert.com>
To: me@example.com
Subject: Urgent: Your account has been limited

Dear Customer,
We noticed unusual login attempts from a new device. To restore full access, please verify your information within 24 hours, or your account will be permanently suspended.
Click here to verify: http://paypal-verification-help.com/login
Alternatively, open the attached Verification_Form.html and submit the details.

Regards,
PayPal Team
Case ID: PP-392847

What are the red flags here, and what should I do if (a) I haven’t clicked anything yet, or (b) I clicked the link but didn’t enter any info?

I’m a parent making a simple tech agreement for my 11-year-old who wants to use TikTok and Discord. Can you draft: (1) a short checklist of 6–8 plain-language rules covering privacy, screen time, respectful behavior, accepting friend requests, sharing photos/location, and what to do if something feels wrong; and (2) a quick list of the key safety settings to enable in TikTok and in Discord, with where to find them in the apps?

We just moved into a 2-bedroom rental apartment with a very curious 14‑month‑old. Details: 5th‑floor balcony with slatted railing (about 5" gaps), open kitchen with gas stove knobs at the front, lots of low drawers, tall unanchored bookshelves, casement windows with only screens (no guards), standard outlets, and a bathroom with cleaners under the sink. We also have a cat and a litter box. Our landlord doesn’t want holes drilled if possible. Can you give me a short, prioritized checklist of renter‑friendly childproofing steps (including the balcony and windows), plus the key product types to buy this weekend?

I’m getting my parents’ house ready for my 2‑year‑old’s weekend visit. Quick context: backyard pool without a safety fence, stairs with no gate, a wood fireplace, older blinds with cords, medications in a low kitchen cabinet, some houseplants, cleaning supplies in the laundry room, and a friendly dog. Can you provide a concise, room‑by‑room hazard checklist with temporary fixes we can do in a day (minimal purchases), the top 8 items to prioritize, and what to include in a basic first‑aid kit and emergency info sheet to post on the fridge?

Can you sanity-check our car seat setup? Our son is 2 years 9 months old, 30 lb, 36 in. He rides rear-facing in a Graco Extend2Fit convertible installed in a 2018 Subaru Forester. Is it still safer to keep him rear-facing, and if so, how long can we do that with this seat? If we switch to forward-facing eventually, what should we change (harness height, recline, top tether)? We currently use LATCH in the outboard position—should we switch to seat belt for higher weight limits?

Flying with a toddler question: We’re taking a 3-hour domestic flight with our 18‑month‑old (22 lb) and then renting a car at the destination. We own a Cosco Scenera Next. What’s the simplest, safest way to handle the flight and the car rental—bring the seat onboard or gate check? If we bring it, how do we check that it’s FAA‑approved and where should we install it on the plane? Any tips for installing that seat quickly in a compact rental car?

Can you write a short post I can paste into our neighborhood Facebook group asking for after-school babysitter recommendations? Details: we’re in Brookline (Coolidge Corner), need Mon–Thu 3:00–6:30 pm starting Jan 6, for one 7-year-old. Duties: school pickup (0.4 mi walk), snack, homework help, occasional playdate driving (we have a booster). Pay $28–$32/hr DOE, W-2 preferred, must be vaccinated and comfortable with a friendly cat. Please keep it under 90 words and include that people should DM me.

I’m interviewing babysitters for my 18-month-old who has a mild egg allergy and separation anxiety. Could you give me 6 concise interview questions tailored to this, plus 4 red flags to watch for during the interview or a trial? Keep the answers brief.

My 3-year-old starts daycare next week and cries/clings at drop-off. Can you give me a simple 5-step morning and drop-off routine, a two-sentence goodbye script, and three ideas for a small comfort item we can send that most centers allow?

We just moved and my 10-year-old is starting a new school on Monday. They’re anxious about getting lost and making friends. Please share a short night-before checklist (5 items), a 60-second morning pep-talk script I can say, and three easy ways they can meet one new person at lunch.

We’re expecting our second child in 6 weeks, and our 3-year-old has gotten clingy and is fighting bedtime. Can you give me 5 practical things we can do over the next month to prepare her, plus 3 simple scripts to handle jealousy and visitors, and one idea for a “big sibling job” she can do during feeds?

My 8-year-old son (autistic, loves trains, sensitive to noise) is getting a baby sister next month via scheduled C-section. Could you write a brief 6-panel social story script to prepare him for the hospital and first day home, and suggest 3 sensory-friendly home adjustments and 3 low-pressure ways he can help with the baby?

My 3-year-old has had a fever up to 102.4°F since last night along with a runny nose and a mild cough. He’s fussy but still plays a bit, is drinking some water, and ate very little. I gave 5 mL children’s acetaminophen (160 mg/5 mL) at 8 pm; it brought the fever down to about 100°F but it rose again around 1 am. No rash, breathing seems normal, and vaccines are up to date. He weighs about 14 kg. What can I do at home overnight to keep him comfortable, and when should I worry enough to call the doctor or go to urgent care? Is it okay to alternate acetaminophen and ibuprofen, and what intervals should I use?

Could you give me a simple home-care plan for a likely stomach bug in my 6-year-old? She started vomiting around 5 am (4 times total) and has had watery diarrhea 3 times today. Low-grade fever 100.2°F, some belly cramping, tired but alert. Last pee was around 2 pm and her mouth seems a bit dry. She weighs about 20 kg. We have Pedialyte at home. How should I rehydrate her tonight (how much and how often), what foods should we try or avoid, what warning signs mean we should seek care, and when is it okay for her to go back to school?

I’m 4 weeks postpartum after a C‑section with a newborn and a very active 3‑year‑old. We live in a small apartment, no nearby family, and my partner works shifts. I’m exhausted and short on time. Could you: (1) suggest a gentle 10‑minute at‑home self‑care routine I can realistically do once a day, (2) give me 3 quick “micro‑reset” stress relievers I can do during night feeds without waking the baby, and (3) provide a short, kind script I can use to ask my partner for a 30‑minute break each day without sounding accusatory or guilty?

I’m a WFH dad of an 8‑year‑old with ADHD. Meltdowns and interruptions leave me stressed and guilty. I can carve out about 15 minutes in the morning and 15 minutes in the evening, can’t leave the house easily, and I have a phone, a yoga mat, and headphones. Please give me: (1) a simple weekly self‑care plan that fits those two 15‑minute blocks, (2) 3 five‑minute grounding techniques I can do next to my child during tough moments, and (3) 3 kinder self‑talk reframes for when I feel like a “bad parent.”
